description: An Urartian fortress and city founded in 782 BCE by King Argishti I atop Arin Berd hill, marking the foundation of modern Yerevan. The museum, opened in 1968 for the city's 2750th anniversary, displays over 12,758 artifacts from pre-Urartian through early Armenian periods.
highlights: Famous cuneiform inscription confirming 782 BCE founding by Argishti I
Excavated palace, royal assembly hall, temples, and over 100 rooms
Artifacts including pottery, belt buckles, bracelets, helmets, arrows, and silver coins
161 collections spanning Urartian, Achaemenian, Hellenistic periods
Name 'Erebuni' endures in modern 'Yerevan' - direct historical connection
tips: Visit both the museum and the archaeological site on the hill
Allow 1-2 hours to properly explore the collections
Best visited in morning or late afternoon to avoid midday heat
Educational and scientific center offering deep dive into ancient history
Continuously inhabited site that branched out to become modern Yerevan
vibe: Ancient and awe-inspiring, connecting visitors to Yerevan's 2,800-year heritage through mighty Urartian ruins and treasures from the dawn of Armenian civilization
